messageBody:
On 12/8/05, Rakesh Patel <rakesh.mailgroups@...> wrote:
>
> Hi Cedric,
>
> if i write a test against my interface then i am essentially writing a
> functional test. Thats not terrible except for the fact that as its so
> high up i will probably have to wire up the layers beneath, which you
> mention.
>
> So for my high level test, I end up doing this:
>
> protected void setUp() throws Exception {
> super.setUp();
> fs = new FetserverSoapBindingImpl();
> ls = new LogonServiceImpl(manager, "testCache");
> ps = new PostcodeServiceMockImpl();
>
> ((FetserverSoapBindingImpl) fs).setLs(ls);
> ((FetserverSoapBindingImpl) fs).setPs(ps);
> }
>
> which is wiring up all my classes. Fortunately, i may have dummy
> implementations instead i can use (PostcodeServiceMockImpl for example).
>
> I don't have a big issue doing this because i intend to use Spring which
> will allow wiring up beans like this in a much simpler fashion.


Looks good to me, especially if you are going to use dependency injection to
remove even the hardcoded Impl mentions from your code.

Note that TestNG's data providers could come up handy for this as well to
let you test several implementations in the same test method:

@Test(dataProviderName = "server-implementations")
public void verifyServer(FetServerBinding binding) {
...
}

@DataProvider(name = "server-implementations")
public Object[][] provideSoapImplementation() {
return new Object[][] {
{ new FetserverSoapBindingImpl() },
{ new FetserverRpcBindingImpl() }
}
}

and of course, dependency injection could be used on the data provider as
well so that even the class names of these implementations are no longer
hardcoded in your Java source.
